title: Three more NSW apartment towers have ‘significant issues’
text:
For cautious new apartment buyers, Opal and Mascot Towers may just be the tip of the iceberg.

The NSW Building Commissioner has warned property owners to adopt a “buyer beware” approach to inspecting and purchasing homes, after advising that three more apartment towers have “serious issues”.

David Chandler, who was selected by the Berejiklian government three months ago to tackle issues of accountability in the construction industry in NSW, made the comments in the wake of new discoveries of more failing apartment buildings in the state, according to The Daily Telegraph.

Mr Chandler said another building, with 200 apartments, had been identified as having “significant issues” and was “incomplete”, despite receiving certification to be occupied by residents.

He said there were at least two more buildings in the state that had been identified as having similar problems.

The industry entered into a crisis following the emergency evacuation of Mascot Towers in June, an event which followed the emergency evacuation of residents of the Opal building on Christmas Eve last year – both due to rapid and dangerous deterioration of the structures.

Mr Chandler said the responsibility to identify buildings with these types of issues, where the buildings had received certification but structural problems arose, fell back to prospective owners. He suggested these owners could “spend more time” seeking out issues before they purchased a home.

He said owners “should go and spend a little bit more time having a look (at their apartment) before they settle”. Mr Chandler said “60 to 70” per cent of developers were producing a high quality product.

He suggested people buying off the plan could “do a little bit of research to work out who might be risky and who’s less risky” to increase confidence in the market.

Mr Chandler made the comments last night during a state parliament estimates hearing.



A petition started by one of the residents of Mascot Towers, Andrew Burrell calling for a “Royal Commission into the Building Industry” has now gathered more than 27,000 signatures.

Mr Burrell’s petition has called for the “overhaul the way buildings we call our homes are designed, approved, built, certified for occupation, insured, financed, and managed”, saying recent issues coming to light were the “tip of the iceberg”.

News.com.au contacted the Mr Chandler regarding the comments but did not receive a response.
description: The NSW Building Commissioner has warned property owners to adopt a “buyer beware” approach to inspecting and purchasing homes, after advising that three more apartment towers have “serious issues”.
